text: , also known as Yuan-chia li or Yuan-jia li, was a Japanese lunisolar calendar (genka reki).Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Calendar" in Japan Encyclopedia, pp. 98-99; Reischauer, Robert Karl (1937). Early Japanese history, pp. 140, 162. It was used from 604 to 696.Nussbaum, "Genka-reki" at p. 238; Bramsen, William. (1880). Japanese chronological tables, p. 25. ==History== The calendar was created in 425 during the Genka era in Chinese history.Japan, Monbushō. (1876). An outline history of Japanese education: prepared for the Philadelphia International Exhibition, 1876, p. 160. The Genka-reki system was brought to Japan from Korea by a Buddhist monk.Needham, Joseph. (1959). Science and civilisation in China, Mathematics and the sciences of the heavens and the earth, Vol. 3, p. 391 note d. The earliest record of this calendar in Japan is in the 10th month of the 10th year of the reign of Empress Suiko (602). Dates in the Nihon Shoki before the late 7th century were likely recorded using the Genka calendar system.Barnes, Gina Lee. (2007). State Formation in Japan: Emergence of a 4th-Century Ruling Elite, p. 226 n.5. ==Related pages== * Japanese calendar * Sexagenary cycle * Gihō calendar * Taien calendar * Goki calendar * Semmyō calendar ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, Japanese Calendar" Category:Calendars Category:7th-century establishments in Japan Category:7th- century disestablishments in Japan Category:600s establishments Category:5th- century works
title: Genka calendar
